captions.zh:
欢迎来到EchoMind回声思维。

您现在收听的这期播客，是对原英文博客基于 AI 技术生成的中文版本。我们不仅搬运优质内容，还保留原汁原味的嘉宾音色。

我是Lorraine，在互联网大厂从事数据科学，同时也是一名 AI 深度爱好者。本期内容来自斯坦福大学 Andrew Huberman 教授的播客。Huberman 教授将带你探讨：我们的大脑如何控制免疫系统。从哈佛医学院关于针灸的最新研究，到睡眠中大脑的自我清洁机制，再到如何通过呼吸和心态来增强免疫力——这些都不是玄学。如果你对神经科学、免疫系统，或者如何用科学方法优化健康感兴趣，这期节目一定不会让你失望。

好，让我们开始吧。
captions.en: [Introduction by Lorraine]

captions.zh: 欢迎来到Huberman Lab播客，我们聊聊科学和日常生活中的科学工具。
captions.en: Welcome to the Huberman Lab Podcast, where we discuss science and science-based tools for everyday life.

captions.zh: 我是Andrew Huberman，斯坦福医学院的神经生物学和眼科教授。
captions.en: I'm Andrew Huberman, and I'm a professor of neurobiology and ophthalmology at Stanford School of Medicine.

captions.zh: 今天我们聊聊免疫系统，还有神经系统，就是大脑、脊髓，以及它们和身体各器官的联系。
captions.en: Today, we are discussing the immune system, and we are also discussing the nervous system, which is the brain spinal cord and the connections of the brain and spinal cord with all the organs of the body.

captions.zh: 我们还会聊聊怎么用神经系统激活和控制免疫系统。
captions.en: We are also going to discuss how the nervous system can be used to activate and control the immune system.

captions.zh: "大概十几二十年前，要是有人说大脑能控制免疫系统，可能会被学术会议嘲笑，论文也发不出来。但现在，有几十甚至上百篇高质量的同行评审研究，探讨大脑和神经系统如何激活免疫系统。"
captions.en: Now, about 10, 20 years ago, if somebody said that the mind could control the immune system, they'd probably get laughed out of most academic conferences and certainly the work wouldn't be published in quality journals, but nowadays, there are dozens, if not hundreds, of quality peer-reviewed studies on how the mind and how the nervous system can control activation of the immune system.

captions.zh: 这是个很棒的研究领域。而且我给你透露一下我们要聊的内容，就在上周，《Nature》这本顶级科学期刊，发表了一篇相关论文，非常严格的审稿标准。
captions.en: This is a wonderful growing body of research, and just to give you a hint of where we are headed with this, just this last week, there was a paper published in Nature, which is the apex journal for scientific publishing, premier journal, extremely stringent.

captions.zh: "哈佛医学院Chufu Ma的实验室在《Nature》上发表了一篇论文，研究针灸如何减少身体的炎症。等会我会详细讲讲这项研究。他们发现，通过特定方式刺激身体特定部位，可以释放出一些细胞和分子，增强免疫系统功能，可能用来对抗不同类型的感染。"
captions.en: A paper published in Nature from Chufu Ma's lab at Harvard Medical School explored how acupuncture can reduce inflammation in the body and I will describe this study in a bit more detail later, but what they discovered was that by stimulating the body in particular ways at particular sites on the body, they were able to liberate certain cells and molecules that enhance the function of the immune system and potentially can be used to combat different types of infection.

captions.zh: 还有个小提示，他们发现一种叫筋膜的组织，有些人可能听说过。
captions.en: And just to give you another little hint, they found that a particular type of organ tissue called fascia, some of you may have heard of fascia.

captions.zh: "筋膜包裹着我们的肌肉。"
captions.en: Fascia surrounds our muscles.

captions.zh: "乍一看，你可能觉得这是一种没用的组织。"
captions.en: Just to look at it, you might think it's a kind of useless tissue.

captions.zh: "它有点像一个包裹肌肉的密实袋子。"
captions.en: It's sort of like a dense bag in which the muscles are contained.

captions.zh: 其实这些密实袋子比我们想的聪明多了。
captions.en: Well, it turns out that those dense bags are much smarter than we thought.

captions.zh: 它们自己没法思考，但通过刺激身体上特定位置的筋膜，有一条路径直接通向一个叫肾上腺髓质的器官。
captions.en: They don't have a mind of their own, but by stimulating the fascia in a particular location on the body, there's a pathway leading out of that fascia directly to an organ called the adrenal medulla.

captions.zh: 我来解释一下这是什么意思。
captions.en: I'll explain what all this means.

captions.zh: "这样可以释放出一些化学物质，能有效抗炎。"
captions.en: That could liberate particular chemicals that had a potent anti-inflammatory effect.

captions.zh: 所以我们基本上是在说，神经系统就像身体各组织间的高速公路，调动免疫系统，释放出一些能减轻炎症、加速愈合的分子。
captions.en: So what we're basically saying is that the nervous system acts as a set of highways between the different tissues of your body, calling into action the immune system, liberating particular molecules that can reduce inflammation and lead to faster healing.

captions.zh: "我会解释这些是怎么运作的，还有一些不用针灸就能激活和增强免疫系统的方法。"
captions.en: And I will explain how all of that works as well as some other non-acupuncture methods for activating and enhancing the function of the immune system.

captions.zh: "所以今天我们要聊聊如何用大脑治愈，完全没有神秘和抽象的成分。"
captions.en: So today we're going to be talking all about healing with the mind in a completely non-mystical, non-abstract sense.

captions.zh: 在开始之前，我想强调一下，这个播客跟我在斯坦福的教学和研究工作没关系。
captions.en: Before we begin, I'd like to emphasize that this podcast is separate from my teaching and research roles at Stanford.

captions.zh: 其实这也是我想努力做到的，就是免费给大家科普科学和相关工具。
captions.en: It is however, part of my desire and effort to bring zero cost to consumer information about science and science-related tools to the general public.

captions.zh: 好，咱们聊聊免疫系统和神经系统，它们怎么互相作用，以及如何调节免疫系统让它更好地为你服务。
captions.en: Okay, let's talk about the immune system and the nervous system and how the two interact and how you can control your immune system to serve you better.

captions.zh: 我们会聊很多机制上的科学，还有一些细节。
captions.en: We are going to talk a lot of mechanistic science, a little bit of detail.

captions.zh: 你会学到一些关于免疫系统的新词汇，比如不同细胞类型的名字等等，但我保证不管你背景如何，我都会讲得很清楚。
captions.en: You learned some new language around the immune system, names of the different cell types and so forth, but I promise to make it all very clear regardless of your background.

captions.zh: 我们也会聊到很多实用工具。
captions.en: We are also going to discuss a lot of tools.

captions.zh: 我想很多人来这儿是想知道怎么增强免疫系统功能。
captions.en: And I think many of you are probably here because you want to know what you can do in order to boost or enhance the function of your immune system.

captions.zh: 这是个很合理的问题。
captions.en: That's a very reasonable question to ask.

captions.zh: "我想先说，如果你在网上搜这个问题，会得到很多答案。"
captions.en: I want to begin by just acknowledging that if one were to put that question into the internet, you would get back a lot of answers.

captions.zh: "现在有一种通用的答案值得尊重，但我们今天不聊这个。"
captions.en: And there is now a sort of generic form of that answer that deserves our respect, but is not going to be the topic of conversation today.

captions.zh: 我还是想提一下，列举几个我们知道能让身体更健康的方法。
captions.en: I just want to tip my hat to it, however, and list off a few of the things that we know set us up to be healthier than we would be if we didn't do these things.

captions.zh: 所以首先，当然是所有身心健康的基础，就是要有充足的睡眠，也就是要睡够你需要的深度睡眠。
captions.en: So the first of course, is the foundation of all mental and physical health, which is to get adequate sleep, meaning enough sleep, whatever it is for you that you require to get deep sleep.

captions.zh: 所以，睡眠质量要高，而且时间要对，不能今天白天睡，明天晚上睡，这样身体会受不了。
captions.en: So it's got to be of high quality and to time that sleep correctly, meaning you can't sleep during the day one day and at night the next day and expect your system to function well.

captions.zh: 之前我们在节目里也聊过这个，大部分时间要有相对固定的作息，最好能达到80%甚至90%。但生活中，咱们不可能总是按时睡觉起床，对吧？
captions.en: Talked a lot about that before on this podcast, you need a relatively consistent sleep schedule most of the time, about 80% of the time, or even better would be 90% of the time, but the realities of life make it that we can't always go to bed at the same time and wake up at the exact same time, okay?

captions.zh: 所以我们得好好睡觉。
captions.en: So we need sleep.

captions.zh: 阳光也是必须的。
captions.en: We do need sunshine.

captions.zh: "为什么我们需要阳光呢？"
captions.en: Why do we need sunshine?

captions.zh: 因为阳光能帮我们调节生物钟，让细胞里的基因在正确的时间表达。
captions.en: Because it sets our rhythm into a regular state where the genes in all of our cells can be expressed at the correct times.

captions.zh: 我们就像一个细胞工厂，只有知道什么时候该启动，什么时候该休息，这个工厂才能正常运转。
captions.en: We're sort of a factory of cells, if you will, and that factory can only run properly if it knows when certain things should be active and when certain cells should not be active.

captions.zh: "最好的方法就是早晚都晒晒太阳，晚上别让眼睛接触太多亮光。"
captions.en: And the best way to coordinate all of those activities of all the cells is to get sunshine in your eyes in the morning and again, in the evening, and not to get too much bright light in your eyes in the middle of the night.

captions.zh: 这就是基础。
captions.en: That's just foundational.

captions.zh: 然后网上的各种清单都会告诉你，要睡好觉，多晒太阳，多锻炼。
captions.en: And then any lists that you'll find on any number of websites on the internet would say, okay, get good sleep, get sun, get exercise.

captions.zh: 运动量要多少？
captions.en: How much exercise?

captions.zh: 我们每周应该做150到180分钟的二级有氧运动。
captions.en: We should all be getting 150 to 180 minutes of zone two cardio.

captions.zh: 那就是那种一周做150到180分钟，运动时还能勉强聊天的有氧运动。
captions.en: That's cardiovascular exercise where we can just barely hold a conversation or maybe not per week.

captions.zh: 我们应该吃得健康。
captions.en: We should be eating well.

captions.zh: 总是有人告诉我们要吃得健康。
captions.en: We're always told we have to get good nutrition.

captions.zh: "对你来说，健康饮食的意义可能跟别人不一样，但我们都知道，饮食摄入和食物质量，特别是少吃加工食品，这很重要。"
captions.en: What good nutrition means to you is going to be different than what it means to somebody else, but we acknowledge that food intake and quality of food in particular, avoiding processed foods, that's going to be important.

captions.zh: "社交很重要。"
captions.en: Social connection is important.

captions.zh: "多喝水也很重要。"
captions.en: Hydration is important.

captions.zh: "你开始明白了吧。"
captions.en: You're starting to get the picture.

captions.zh: "这些都是有用的，对身心健康很基础。"
captions.en: We can take all that, acknowledge it as useful and foundational for mental and physical health.

captions.zh: "但还是有很多人经常生病，或者伤口、感染好得慢，还有的要长期应对慢性病。"
captions.en: But of course there are many people who still struggle with getting ill too often or with not being able to heal from physical injuries and wounds or from various bacterial and viral infections quickly enough or deal with chronic disease.

captions.zh: 所以今天我们就聊聊怎么用好这些信息，认同并践行。
captions.en: And so today's really about how you can take all of that information, acknowledge it and follow it.

captions.zh: "不过，你还可以通过一些方法来调动神经系统，从而大大增强免疫系统的功能。"
captions.en: But in addition to that, there are things that you can do to leverage your nervous system in order to enhance the function of your immune system in very robust ways.

captions.zh: 所以我想把话题转到这上面来。
captions.en: So that's where I'd like to shift the conversation to.

captions.zh: 首先我们得聊聊免疫系统是什么，它是怎么运作的。
captions.en: The first topic we have to attack is the question of what is the immune system and how does it work?

captions.zh: "我想很多人都听说过抗体、杀伤细胞，还有参与免疫系统的身体器官，比如骨髓、脾脏、胸腺和淋巴结。"
captions.en: I think many of you have heard of antibodies or killer cells or the various organs of the body that are involved in the immune system, like the bone marrow, the spleen, the thymus and the lymph nodes.

captions.zh: 我想简单介绍一下免疫系统基础知识。
captions.en: I'd like to just take a moment and do a sort of brief immune system 101.

captions.zh: 简单说一下免疫系统的基本组成，这样大家就能明白免疫系统怎么运作，有哪些基本部分。
captions.en: Really simple, cover the basic elements of the immune system so that everyone listening or watching this can get a clear sense of how the immune system functions and what its basic parts are.

captions.zh: "对有些人来说，这可能太基础了。"
captions.en: For some of you, this might be too basic.

captions.zh: 可能有些背景知识你已经知道了。
captions.en: It might be a little bit of background that you already know.

captions.zh: 我觉得对大多数人来说，这些信息可能是新的。
captions.en: I think for most of you, this information will be new.

captions.zh: "我保证，你不用生物或医学背景也能理解。"
captions.en: And I promise you, you don't need a biology or medicine background in order to understand this.

captions.zh: "其实很简单，因为它的设计真的很巧妙。"
captions.en: It's actually really simple because it is truly elegant in design.

captions.zh: 你身体有三道主要防线来保护健康。
captions.en: You have three main layers of defense for your health.

captions.zh: "这三道防线一直在帮你抵御细菌、病毒和寄生虫的入侵和疾病。"
captions.en: These are the three things that are constantly at work to protect you from invasion and illness, from bacteria, from viruses and from parasites.

captions.zh: 第一道防线就是我们常说的皮肤，它是个物理屏障。
captions.en: And the first of those three is a physical barrier that we call your skin.

captions.zh: 这听起来可能显而易见，但你所有东西都被皮肤包着。
captions.en: And that might seem kind of obvious, but everything about you is contained in this compartment that is boundaried by your skin.

captions.zh: 而且皮肤是免疫系统的重要部分。
captions.en: And your skin is a very important aspect of your immune system.

captions.zh: "如果你受过伤，其实就是免疫系统的防线被破了。"
captions.en: If you've ever had a cut, you essentially have a breach of the boundary that is your immune system.

captions.zh: "你会发现会有很多变化发生。"
captions.en: And you would notice a number of things would happen.

captions.zh: "你可能会发现伤口周围有点肿。"
captions.en: You might get some swelling around that cut.

captions.zh: "可能会结痂。"
captions.en: You might get a scab.

captions.zh: "过段时间可能会结痂。"
captions.en: Likely you would get a scab over time.

captions.zh: "如果弄脏了，可能有细菌进去了。"
captions.en: If it got dirty, there were some bacteria that got in there.

captions.zh: "你可能会看到有些白细胞聚集，就是脓。"
captions.en: You might see some accumulation of white blood cells, what's called pus.

captions.zh: 我知道有点恶心，但就是这么回事。
captions.en: I know it's kind of gross, but that's what that is.

captions.zh: 可能会变黄，因为有死细胞聚集。
captions.en: It might take on a yellow tint because of the accumulation of some dead cells there.

captions.zh: 但其实皮肤就是主要的防护墙，把外面的有害东西挡在外面。
captions.en: But basically your skin is the primary barrier through which you keep things from the outside that could harm you from getting to the inside.

captions.zh: "现在，还是在第一类，你的身体和外表面是有开口的，对吧？"
captions.en: Now, still in category one, your body and your external surface, you have openings to that surface, right?

captions.zh: "你不只是一个圆形或身体形状，完全被皮肤包裹住。"
captions.en: You're not just a round or a body shaped, completely covered up with skin.

captions.zh: 你有开口。
captions.en: You have openings.

captions.zh: 那些开口是啥？
captions.en: What are those openings?

captions.zh: 那我们从头开始往下说。
captions.en: Well, let's start at the top and work our way down.

captions.zh: "眼睛是感染的主要入口。"
captions.en: A primary site of potential infection are your eyes.

captions.zh: 你有耳朵，有鼻孔，还有嘴巴，对吧？
captions.en: You have your ears, you have your nostrils, you have your mouth, okay?

captions.zh: "这些都是东西进入你身体的主要途径。"
captions.en: Those are going to be the primary sites by which things can get into your system.

captions.zh: 你得让东西进入你的身体。
captions.en: And you need to put things into your system.

captions.zh: 你得吃喝，也得让光线进入身体。
captions.en: You need to drink and eat, and you need to get light into your system.

captions.zh: 所以才有这些开口。
captions.en: That's why you have those openings.

captions.zh: 但坏东西，也就是能伤害你的东西，也能通过这些入口进去。
captions.en: But bad things, meaning things that can harm you, can get into those systems.

captions.zh: 然后呢，从喉咙到胃，再到消化系统，经过肠子到肛门，其实就是一根管子。你基本上就是一串管子。
captions.en: And then of course, along the back of your throat, all the way down to your stomach and your digestive system, and through your intestines and out your rectum, you have a tube that you are basically a series of tubes.

captions.zh: 我之前在播客里也说过，这就是你从外界获取营养的管道之一。
captions.en: I've said that before in this podcast, and this is one such tube by which you extract nutrients from the outside environment.

captions.zh: "但这整根管子，包括你的鼻子和嘴巴，都是有黏液的。"
captions.en: But all along that tube, including your nose and your mouth, it's lined with mucus.

captions.zh: 而且虽然有些人觉得黏液有点恶心，但你越了解它，就越觉得黏液真的很神奇。
captions.en: And while mucus might seem kind of gross to some of you, the more you learn about mucus, the more you realize that mucus is really, really cool.

captions.zh: 因为黏液就像过滤器，可以捕捉细菌和病毒。
captions.en: Because mucus essentially acts as a filter, as a trap for bacteria and viruses.

captions.zh: 而且它还有办法清除或杀死那些细菌和病毒。
captions.en: And it has certain ways of scrubbing or killing those bacteria and viruses.

captions.zh: 现在，这些黏液一直在更新。
captions.en: Now, the mucus is constantly being turned over.

captions.zh: "等会我们会聊到，黏液的化学成分很重要，能阻挡一些东西进入你的身体，同时让其他东西通过，这样你就能从中吸收营养。"
captions.en: As we'll talk about later, the chemistry of that mucus is really important in order to make sure that certain things don't make it into your system, and other things are allowed to move through your system, and you can extract nutrients from them.

captions.zh: "我先讲免疫系统这第一道防线，是想让你想象自己是个独立的个体，你需要吸收对的东西，挡住或者消灭不对的东西。"
captions.en: So the reason I'm talking about this first category of barrier for immune system in such detail is I'd like you to envision yourself as a human, of course, but as a human that is a clear entity from everything else, and you have to bring in the right things, and you have to keep out the wrong things or kill them.

captions.zh: "不过，细菌、病毒和寄生虫还是会进到我们身体里。"
captions.en: Now, inevitably, bacteria, viruses, and parasitic infections are going to make their way into our body.

captions.zh: "但它们会不会被消灭，或是引发问题，就要看第二、第三层了。"
captions.en: But whether or not they are killed off, or whether or not they take over and cause us harm is going to be determined by layers two and three.

captions.zh: "第二层和第三层就是所谓的先天免疫系统和适应性免疫系统。"
captions.en: So layers two and three are the so-called innate immune system and the adaptive immune system.

captions.zh: "所以，先天免疫系统就是我说的第二道防线，反应很快。"
captions.en: So the innate immune system is what I would call the second layer of defense, it's very fast.

captions.zh: "所以不管是细菌、病毒还是寄生虫，一旦进到你身体里，比如你吃下去了，或者通过眼睛进来的，或者你和带病的人握手后又揉了眼睛，接下来会发生什么呢？"
captions.en: So whether or not it's bacteria, virus, or parasite, what happens when you have something enter your body, maybe you swallowed it, maybe it got in through your eyes, maybe you shook somebody's hand who was carrying a particular kind of illness, and then you wiped your eyes.

captions.zh: 我之前在这个播客里说过，其实我们见到别人后，通常在30秒内，大多数人就会不自觉地把对方的化学物质抹在自己脸上或者身体上。
captions.en: And I've talked about on this podcast before, very soon after we meet another person, usually within 30 seconds, believe it or not, most people wipe that person's chemicals somewhere on their face or on their body surface.

captions.zh: "这已经反复被证明了。"

captions.en: It's designed to slow circulation of the blood, increased circulation of the lymph and the other killer cells in the body, reduce the probability of infecting others by reducing its thought diarrhea and vomit, but also breathing on others, interacting with others.

captions.zh: 有时候，人一生病就会有种退回到童年的感觉，特别是成年人，会特别想被照顾。
captions.en: And in some cases it will activate this, I don't want to call it a regressed state, but many people feel somewhat more, if they are adults, they feel more childlike when they are ill and they want to be taken care of very badly.

captions.zh: 有些可能是后天学的，有些可能是天生的，我们也不太清楚。
captions.en: Some of it might be learned, some of it might be innate, we don't know.

captions.zh: 不过，生病时的反应有几个有趣的地方。
captions.en: But the sickness behavior is very interesting for a couple of reasons.

captions.zh: "首先，它很像神经科学文献里提到的重度抑郁状态。"
captions.en: First of all, it mimics another state that has been described in the neuroscience literature, which is major depression.

captions.zh: 生病的人，不管是细菌病毒感染还是重度抑郁，体内的白介素-6和肿瘤坏死因子α水平都会明显升高。
captions.en: And in both sick individuals, sick from bacterial viral infection, and in people with major depression, it's been shown that there are robust increases in the levels of interleukin-6 and tumor necrosis factor alpha.

captions.zh: 所以现在有个说法是，抑郁可能和这些炎症因子活跃有关。
captions.en: So there is an idea now circulating that depression involves these inflammatory cytokines being very active.

captions.zh: 而且我们知道生病时这些炎症因子会特别活跃。
captions.en: And we know that illness involves inflammatory cytokines being very active.

captions.zh: "所以如果你想想，重度抑郁和生病的相似性，应该能指引我们找到一些方法，帮助我们预防或更快康复。"
captions.en: So if you think about it, the similarity between major depression and being sick ought to be able to point us in a direction of interventions that could help us either prevent illness or move through illness more quickly.

captions.zh: "但在我们朝这个方向走的时候，我想强调一下，生病的表现其实是免疫系统和神经系统之间的桥梁。"
captions.en: But as we head in that direction, because indeed that's the case, I just want to emphasize that sickness behavior is what provides this bridge between the immune system and the nervous system.

captions.zh: "而且我们很快会发现，健康的行为，比如能避免感染的行为，也能清楚地显示神经系统和免疫系统之间的联系。"
captions.en: And what we'll soon see also is that healthy behavior, behavior that allows us to avoid infection also points to a clear bridge between the nervous system and the immune system.

captions.zh: "我们不只是有大脑、身体和器官，还有个免疫系统。"
captions.en: That it isn't just that we have a brain and body and our organs, and then we have an immune system.

captions.zh: "没错，它们一直在互相作用。"
captions.en: That's true, but they're interacting all the time.

captions.zh: "这会让我们明白，某些思维模式和行为选择能增强免疫系统功能，反之亦然，这一点也不意外。"
captions.en: And this is going to lead us to a place where it's going to be very clear and not at all surprising how certain patterns of thinking and certain behaviors that we can elect to take can help enhance our immune system function and vice versa.

captions.zh: "其实生病时还有两个特点值得注意。"
captions.en: There are two other features of sickness behavior definitely worth pointing out.

captions.zh: “一个理论是，生病时食欲下降，特别是对高蛋白食物的食欲下降，可能是身体在潜意识中想减少铁的摄入。”
captions.en: One is a theory, which is that the reduced appetite, in particular appetite for protein-rich foods when sick is thought to be an attempt, a subconscious attempt of the organism to reduce the amount of iron that it's taking in.

captions.zh: "一般来说，建议男性每天摄入大约八毫克铁。"
captions.en: Now, typically the amount of iron intake that's recommended or more or less is for men, it's about eight milligrams per day.

captions.zh: "女性的话，每天需要18到27毫克，看她们是否怀孕、哺乳或月经期等情况。"
captions.en: For women, it's anywhere from 18 to 27 milligrams per day, depending on whether or not they're pregnant, lactating or menstruating, et cetera.

captions.zh: "这个范围可能会有变化。"
captions.en: The ranges can vary.

captions.zh: "不过，如果血液中的铁含量太高，比如每天超过45毫克，对身体会很有害。"
captions.en: But, and indeed it's true that if iron levels in the blood go too high, like over 45 milligrams per day can be very toxic to the system.

captions.zh: 但在生物学和健康领域，有个理论比较流行，说食欲下降其实是为了减少铁的摄入，因为很多细菌和感染在血液中铁含量高时更容易繁殖。
captions.en: But the theory that's prominent in the biology literature and in the health literature is that the reduction in appetite is actually an attempt to reduce iron intake specifically because many bacteria and other forms of infection seem to thrive when levels of iron in the blood are high.

captions.zh: "我可不希望有人因为这个就突然开始铁限制饮食来改善健康。"
captions.en: Now, I don't want to see anyone take this to extreme and suddenly do an iron deprivation diet in order to get well.

captions.zh: "不过这个理论挺有意思的，我不提就太可惜了，因为听起来挺有道理的。"
captions.en: But it's an interesting theory that I'd be remiss if I didn't mention, because it makes good sense.

captions.zh: "铁其实是跟血红蛋白和红细胞结合在血液中的。"
captions.en: Iron is actually attached to hemoglobin and red blood cells in the bloodstream.

captions.zh: "这通常对我们帮助挺大的。"
captions.en: Normally that can help us quite a lot.

captions.zh: "对了，铁也在肌肉里，我应该提一下。"
captions.en: It's also in muscle, I should mention that.

captions.zh: 铁可以储存在肌肉里。
captions.en: Iron can be sequestered into muscle.

captions.zh: 铁对健康有很多好处，不过。
captions.en: And iron serves a lot of important health promoting roles, but.

captions.zh: "减少食欲，进而减少铁的摄入，这会降低某些东西的能力，比如感染在体内某些部位的传播。"
captions.en: But by reducing appetite and thereby reducing iron intake, it does reduce the capacity of certain things, including infections, to travel in certain compartments within the body.

captions.zh: 所以这只是个理论，但我想很多人生病时可能都没胃口。
captions.en: So again, that's just theory, but I think many of you are probably familiar with not having an appetite when you're sick.

captions.zh: 而患有重度抑郁的人，常见的就是食欲不振。
captions.en: The other thing that's very typical of people with major depression is loss of appetite.

captions.zh: "不是总这样，但经常会没胃口。"
captions.en: Not always, but often loss of appetite.

captions.zh: 所以这里又看到，生病时没胃口，重度抑郁时也没胃口。
captions.en: So here again, we have loss of appetite in sickness behavior, loss of appetite in major depression.

captions.zh: 而且不意外的是，生病行为和重度抑郁的一个主要症状就是失去兴趣，不仅对社交，对性和生育也没兴趣。
captions.en: And perhaps not surprisingly, one of the major symptoms of sickness behavior and major depression that map more or less onto one another is loss of libido or interest, not just in social interactions, but in sex and reproduction.

captions.zh: 所以你看，生病行为和抑郁症其实很像。
captions.en: And so again, if you think about sickness behavior and depression, they are very, very similar.

captions.zh: 所以，生病行为和重度抑郁有一些共同的核心特征。
captions.en: Okay, so sickness behavior and major depression have certain core features in common.

captions.zh: 所以我们得问自己，为什么生病会影响我们的思维和感知，还会影响食欲，以及我们想要被照顾多少。
captions.en: We need to therefore ask ourselves, why and how does being sick influence the way that we think and perceive our environment and impact our appetite, whether or not we want to be cared for more or cared for less.

captions.zh: "在这方面，人们往往分成两派。"
captions.en: Again, people tend to diverge into two different bins there.

captions.zh: "你可能不信，但这条路径已经找到了。"
captions.en: And believe it or not, the pathway for this has been identified.

captions.zh: "当我们身体某个地方感染，比如头部、鼻窦或者耳朵感染，甚至身体伤口或受伤也会触发这些机制。"
captions.en: When we have an infection someplace in our body, and it could be up in our head, it could be a sinus infection, it could be an ear infection, or I should also mention many of these same mechanisms can also be the consequence of a wound or an injury to the body.

captions.zh: "你知道，像是背部受伤或者椎间盘滑脱，或者说椎间盘突出吧，大家常这么说。"
captions.en: You know, a back injury or a slip disc, or I guess it's called a herniated disc is the way that you hear it described.

captions.zh: "这样一来，我们可能会有点烦躁。"
captions.en: When we have that, we can be kind of irritable.

captions.zh: "我们不想做某些事情，只想一个人待着。"
captions.en: We don't want to do certain things and we just want to be left alone.

captions.zh: "事情变得更难了，怎么回事，为什么呢？"
captions.en: Things are harder, how, why?

captions.zh: 其实，这跟迷走神经有关，它连接身体和大脑，向大脑特定区域传递信号，触发我们说的这种"生病行为"的状态。
captions.en: Well, there's a known pathway, which is the so-called vagus nerve that connects the body and the brain, signals to particular brain sites to engage this category of motivational state that we call sickness behavior.

captions.zh: 很多人可能听过迷走神经，就是V-A-G-U-S，迷走神经。
captions.en: Many of you have probably heard of the vagus, V-A-G-U-S, vagus.

captions.zh: 迷走神经是一条很广泛的神经通路。
captions.en: The vagus nerve is a very extensive nerve pathway.

captions.zh: 这是第十对颅神经，从脑干后面出来，进到身体里，广泛分支连接很多器官，包括我们的肺、心脏、肠道等等。
captions.en: It's the 10th cranial nerve, comes out of the back of the brainstem, heads into the body and branches out extensively to innervate or connect to many of our organs, including our lungs, our heart, our gut, et cetera.

captions.zh: 这些器官也能把神经信号传回大脑。
captions.en: And all of those organs are able also to send neural signals back up to the brain.

captions.zh: 有时候我们听说迷走神经是让自己冷静下来的途径。
captions.en: We sometimes hear the vagus as the route to calming ourselves down.

captions.zh: "可惜，这基本上是个误传，我也不知道怎么传开的。"
captions.en: Unfortunately, that's more or less a myth that I don't know how it got propagated.

captions.zh: 迷走神经里有很多不同的通路。
captions.en: You have lots of different pathways in the vagus.

captions.zh: "其实，刺激迷走神经通常会让人更兴奋、更警觉，不过它确实有很多不同的通路。"
captions.en: Usually vagal stimulation actually creates more arousal and alertness, although it does have multiple pathways.

captions.zh: 不过现在已经有很多研究在不同情况下研究迷走神经，包括在生病时的表现。
captions.en: But there have now been many studies of the vagus in various contexts, including in sickness behavior.

captions.zh: 迷走神经是把身体感染快速传递给大脑的通路，特别是传到下丘脑这个地方，这里有很多不同类型的神经元。
captions.en: And it's very clear that the vagus nerve is the fast pathway by which an infection in the body is signaled to the brain, to a particular location in the brain called the hypothalamus, which harbors a lot of different types of neurons.

captions.zh: 比如说，前视区的神经元会让体温升高，引发发烧，对吧？
captions.en: Neurons, for instance, in the preoptic area that increase body temperature and fever, right?

captions.zh: "这就是为什么升高体温很重要，身体想通过发烧来消灭入侵者。"
captions.en: That's one of the most important things is to increase body temperature in order to, it's the body's attempt to kill off this invader.

captions.zh: "因为很多病毒和细菌在高温下活不久。"
captions.en: Because many viruses and many bacteria don't survive well at elevated heat.

captions.zh: 这就是发烧的作用。
captions.en: That's the function of a fever.

captions.zh: "发烧其实是有作用的。"
captions.en: A fever actually has a functional role.

captions.zh: 所以生物学里，我们喜欢用复杂词。
captions.en: So in biology, we like complicated words.

captions.zh: 所以我们把任何能升高体温或引起发烧的东西叫做pyrogen。
captions.en: So we call anything that increases body temperature or creates a fever, a pyrogen.

captions.zh: "很多年前，我本科时研究过pyrogens，往肚子里注射一种叫脂多糖的东西，然后就会发烧。"
captions.en: Many years ago, in my undergraduate years, I was working on pyrogens, injecting something called lippy polysaccharide into the belly, which then gives you a fever.

captions.zh: "LPS会在肠道引发炎症反应。"
captions.en: The way it does that is LPS causes an inflammation response in the gut.

captions.zh: "肠道不知道发生了什么。"
captions.en: The gut doesn't know what is happening.

captions.zh: "胃细胞也不知道发生了什么。"
captions.en: The stomach cells don't know what's happening.

captions.zh: "所以它们就开始分泌IL-6、IL-1这些细胞因子，杀伤细胞也会跑到肠道里去。"
captions.en: So they just start secreting the IL-6, the IL-1, all those cytokines, the killer cells migrate into the gut.

captions.zh: "所以有时候你感冒不舒服时，会肚子疼。"
captions.en: That's why you sometimes get a stomach ache when you don't feel well, you have a flu or something like it.

captions.zh: "然后神经信号、电信号就传到下丘脑了。"
captions.en: A neural signal, electrical signals get sent up to the hypothalamus.

captions.zh: "下丘脑就会想，我不知道外面怎么了，但有信号说明有事发生了。"
captions.en: The hypothalamus says, oh, I don't know what's going on out there, but there's a signal something's going on.

captions.zh: "那就让身体发热吧。"
captions.en: Let's just heat up the body.

captions.zh: "那就开始把外面的东西烧掉吧。"
captions.en: Let's just start cooking whatever it is out there.

captions.zh: "当然，你不希望发烧太高，因为会伤脑细胞。"
captions.en: And of course, you don't want fever to go too high because you can kill brain cells.

captions.zh: "但在一定范围内，发烧其实是身体的一个自我保护反应，懂吧？"
captions.en: But within a particular range, the fever is a functional and adaptive response, okay?

captions.zh: "所以你吃药降温可能会让你感觉舒服点，但其实这限制了身体为了消灭入侵者而产生的反应。"
captions.en: So if you're taking drugs to try and lower the fever, that might make you feel more comfortable, but actually that's limiting the response that your body is creating in order to try and kill off that invader.

captions.zh: "当然，你也不希望发烧太高。"
captions.en: And again, you don't want fever to go too high.

captions.zh: "这跟年龄有关。"
captions.en: This is going to vary depending on age.

captions.zh: 你可以上网查查发烧可以接受的范围。
captions.en: You can look up online what the range tolerable ranges are for fever.

captions.zh: 但如果你发烧了，想降体温，除非烧得太厉害，否则其实不该这么做，因为这样不利于杀死入侵者。
captions.en: But when you're trying to lower body temperature, when you have a fever, unless you're heading into dangerous levels of heating up, that's actually the wrong way to take your system if you do indeed want to kill off that invader.

captions.zh: 那迷走神经就是快速反应的关键。
captions.en: Okay, so the vagus nerve is the quick response.

captions.zh: 它还会把信号传到大脑，让你对外界的感知改变。
captions.en: It also sends input to areas of the brain that change your perception of the outside world.

captions.zh: "我一说你就懂，就是怕光，对吧？"
captions.en: One of the most obvious of these, obvious once I tell it to you, is photophobia, right?

captions.zh: 我喜欢阳光明媚的天气。
captions.en: I love bright sunshine.

captions.zh: 我想保持清醒的时候就喜欢光线亮一点。
captions.en: I love bright lights when I want to be alert.

captions.zh: 我们每个人对光的敏感度都不一样，但大多数人生病或身体有炎症时，会觉得亮光有点刺眼。
captions.en: We all have different levels of light sensitivity, but most people, when they are sick, when there's an inflammation response in the body, they feel like bright lights are kind of aversive.

captions.zh: 他们会有典型的怕光反应。
captions.en: They get a well-described kind of classical photophobia.

captions.zh: "这其实是通过一个从眼睛到丘脑前核的通路来调节的。"
captions.en: And that's mediated by a pathway that goes from your eye to an area of your thalamus called the anterior nucleus of the thalamus.

captions.zh: "这是哈佛医学院的Clifford Saper做的研究。"
captions.en: This is work that was done by Clifford Saper at Harvard Medical School.

captions.zh: "这研究真挺精彩的。"
captions.en: It's really beautiful work.

captions.zh: 然后从那里到大脑外层，就是脑膜，差不多就是大脑和其他一些结缔组织接触的地方。
captions.en: And then from there up to the outer lining of the brain, which is the meninges, just sort of on the outside of the brain where the brain starts to interface with some of the other connective tissues.

captions.zh: "我们等会儿再详细聊这个。"
captions.en: We'll talk more about these later.

captions.zh: 生病时，这可能会引起畏光和头痛。
captions.en: It can actually create a photophobia and a headache when one is ill.

captions.zh: "那么，这就是路径。"
captions.en: So here's the pathway.

captions.zh: 有东西通过擦眼睛或者从嘴巴进入你体内。
captions.en: Some invader gets into your system because you wiped your eyes or got in through your mouth.

captions.zh: "你没听你妈的话，结果从眼睛进来了。"
captions.en: You didn't listen to your mother and got in through your eyes.

captions.zh: 你觉得不舒服。
captions.en: You're feeling sick.

captions.zh: "这有点不对劲。"
captions.en: Something's going on there.

captions.zh: 你肚子疼是因为那儿发炎了。
captions.en: You have a stomach ache because of all the inflammation there.

captions.zh: "信号是通过迷走神经传上去的。"
captions.en: The signal goes up from your vagus nerve.

captions.zh: 你发烧了。
captions.en: You're heating up with a fever.

captions.zh: 你怕光是因为这个通路激活了，原本能忍受的光现在刺激了丘脑前核。
captions.en: You've got photophobia because you've activated this pathway by which what would normally be tolerable light is triggering this thalamic nucleus, the anterior thalamus.

captions.zh: "这影响到了脑膜。"
captions.en: That's projecting up to the meninges.

captions.zh: 你因为看光而头疼。
captions.en: You've got a headache in response to looking at light.

captions.zh: "这其实就是让你去个安静黑暗的地方休息。"
captions.en: It's basically triggering an overall pathway to get you to go into a quiet, dark place and rest.

captions.zh: 最后我想说的就是休息。
captions.en: And the last element I'd like to talk about is the rest.

captions.zh: "身体到大脑再到下丘脑有个反应被触发了。"
captions.en: There's something that gets triggered from the body to the brain to the hypothalamus.

captions.zh: 我们觉得知道是哪块下丘脑区域出了问题。
captions.en: And we think we know which hypothalamic area it is.

captions.zh: 应该是视上核出问题了。
captions.en: It's the supraoptic nucleus, we think.

captions.zh: "视上核是因为它就在你所谓的视交叉上面。"
captions.en: Supraoptic because it's right above your so-called optic chiasm.

captions.zh: 想知道在哪儿的话，就在你上颚上方。
captions.en: If you want to look up where that is, it's right above the roof of your mouth.

captions.zh: 那儿有些核团会让你白天也想睡觉，正常情况下这可是你生物钟活跃的时候。
captions.en: And there are nuclei there that promote the desire to sleep even during the daytime, what would normally be the active phase of your circadian cycle.

captions.zh: "这就有意思了，因为这里有多条路径在告诉你，避光、减少活动，把让你生病的东西都加热起来。"
captions.en: Now, that is really interesting because what's happening here is you've got multiple pathways that are saying, avoid light, reduce your amount of behavior, heat up all the things that are making you sick.

captions.zh: "这就是病态行为，从身体到大脑，让你做出正确反应。"
captions.en: This is sickness behavior, and it's going from your body to your mind to make you do the right thing.

captions.zh: 现在还有一条慢路径，完全是通过血液传递的，就是所谓的体液因素。不是因为搞笑，体液因素指的是血液中的成分。
captions.en: Now, there's also a slow pathway that's purely mediated by the blood, so-called humoral factors, not because they're funny, but humoral factors are factors of the blood.

captions.zh: "当你感染好几个小时或几天后，IL-6、IL-1、肿瘤坏死因子和其他炎症因子的量开始增加，最后在你血液中的总量高到足以传递给大脑。"
captions.en: As you have an infection for many hours or days, the amount of IL-6 and IL-1 and tumor necrosis factor and other inflammatory cytokines is starting to increase such that the total amount in your circulation gets high enough and is communicated to the brain.

captions.zh: "这些因子通常通过一种叫脉络丛的特殊组织进入大脑，这个很有意思。"
captions.en: And it tends to enter the brain through a particular type of tissue that's really interesting called choroid, C-H-O-R-O-I-D.

captions.zh: "脉络丛真挺有意思的。"
captions.en: Choroid is really interesting.

captions.zh: "脑室就是你大脑里的空腔，里面有脑脊液。"
captions.en: The ventricles are the spaces in your brain, and the spaces in your brain have what's called cerebral spinal fluid in them.

captions.zh: "脑脊液里有很多重要成分，但是脉络丛开始释放和响应这些细胞因子、炎症因子，然后大脑就会开始经历各种炎症变化，影响到神经元。"
captions.en: Cerebral spinal fluid contains a number of important things, but the choroid starts releasing and responding to these cytokines, inflammatory cytokines, and then the brain actually starts to experience all sorts of changes in terms of inflammation to neurons.

captions.zh: "你的记忆力会变差。"
captions.en: Your memory tends to get poor.

captions.zh: "你的认知能力会变差。"
captions.en: Your cognition tends to get poor.

captions.zh: "这些是暂时的情况。"
captions.en: These are transient things.

captions.zh: "通常情况下，这些症状会慢慢消失，但这时候你已经病得很厉害，感觉很糟糕了。"
captions.en: Most often, eventually these things will pass, but this is deep into sickness when you're really feeling lousy.

captions.zh: "你没法读书，看不了电影，什么都干不了。"
captions.en: You can't read, you can't watch a movie, you can't do anything.

captions.zh: 所以如果你生病了，什么都不想做，可能是因为身体有了快速反应，还有个慢一点的反应，就是大脑里有些组织在发出炎症信号，现在整个大脑都在应对或者试图应对这个感染。
captions.en: So if you ever get sick and you just can't be bothered by anything, it's probably because you've had that fast response from the body, and you've also had this slower response where you literally have a set of tissues in your brain that are sending out these inflammatory signals, and now your whole brain is starting to cope or is trying to cope with this infection.

captions.zh: 所以你有快反应和慢反应两种机制。
captions.en: So you've got a slow pathway and a fast pathway.

captions.zh: 听起来真够糟的。
captions.en: That all sounds really terrible.

captions.zh: 所以现在我想聊聊怎么降低生病的概率，其实从一开始感觉不舒服到生病期间，有一些方法可以加快康复速度，把情况扭转过来。
captions.en: So now I'd like to talk about what you can do to reduce the probability of getting sick, and there are actually things that one can do as you start to get sick, and once you're sick, to accelerate the healing process by flipping the equation.

captions.zh: 到目前为止，我们一直在聊身体怎么激活大脑某些区域，导致类似抑郁的生病行为。
captions.en: Up until now, we've been talking about how the body activates certain areas in the brain to create sickness behavior that's very much like depression.

captions.zh: "你可能感冒、流感或者受伤时都经历过这种情况。"
captions.en: You're probably all familiar with this from any time you've had a cold or a flu or something really lousy or an injury.

captions.zh: 现在我们换个角度想想，怎么利用神经系统提升免疫系统功能，让我们更快地从疾病和伤痛中康复呢？
captions.en: Now let's flip the equation and ask, what can we do with our nervous system in order to enhance the function of our immune system in order to be able to heal and recover from illness and injury more quickly?

captions.zh: 假设有天你醒来或者回家时，喉咙有些痒，或者呼吸时鼻子感觉不太对劲。
captions.en: So let's say you are in that unfortunate circumstance of waking up one day or coming home and you've got that tickle in your throat, or when you breathe, your nasal passages don't feel the same way.

captions.zh: 你有点头疼。
captions.en: You've got a little bit of a headache.

captions.zh: 你感觉有点不对劲。
captions.en: You're feeling kind of off.

captions.zh: 我们都知道该怎么做。
captions.en: We all know what we should do.

captions.zh: 大家要多喝水，然后好好睡一觉。
captions.en: We should all hydrate, drink some water, and go to sleep.

captions.zh: "对啊，这就是大家常说的。"
captions.en: Right, that's what we are all told.

captions.zh: "但其实有些事你可以主动去做，帮助免疫系统在感染初期更好地反应。"
captions.en: But there are actually things that you can actively do in order to get your immune system to deploy a more robust response at that early phase of potential infection.

captions.zh: "先聊聊休息这块吧。"
captions.en: Let's focus first on the rest component.

captions.zh: "对啊，大家都说要洗个热水澡然后睡个九十个小时。"
captions.en: Yes, of course, we are all told that we should take a hot shower and go to sleep, you know, and get nine or 10 hours of sleep.

captions.zh: "其实可以从增强免疫系统的角度来看睡眠，很有意思。"
captions.en: But there's an interesting way of looking at sleep specifically for its role in enhancing the immune system.

captions.zh: "有篇很棒的综述，我会放在说明里，专门研究了睡眠对免疫系统支持的不同之处。"
captions.en: And there's a wonderful review, I'll put the review in the captions, that looked specifically at the literature surrounding sleep that is different because it occurs in support of the immune system.

captions.zh: "通常我们晚上刚入睡时，主要是慢波睡眠。"
captions.en: So normally when we go to sleep, we have slow wave sleep predominantly in the early phase of the night.

captions.zh: 然后随着睡得越来越久，我们会进入更多所谓的快速眼动睡眠。
captions.en: And then over time, as we sleep longer and longer, we get more so-called REM, rapid eye movement sleep.

captions.zh: "我们在关于睡眠的节目里聊过这些。"
captions.en: Talked all about this on the episodes on sleep.

captions.zh: 当然，一整晚都有慢波睡眠和快速眼动睡眠，只是它们的比例会变，这两者功能不同。
captions.en: Of course, you have slow wave sleep and REM sleep throughout the night always, but it's the fraction of slow wave sleep to REM sleep that shifts and they have different functions, et cetera.

captions.zh: 有证据显示，感染时的睡眠，尤其是感染早期，和大脑中血清素水平升高有关。可能是适应机制或者其他原因，大脑里所谓的Raphae核的神经元开始释放更多血清素。
captions.en: There is some evidence that the sleep associated with an infection, in particular early stage of infection, is associated with elevated levels of serotonin in the brain that either through an adaptive mechanism or for whatever reason, the neurons in the brain of the so-called Raphae nucleus start releasing more serotonin.

captions.zh: "这些血清素和相关通路可能增强免疫系统功能，帮助对抗感染。"
captions.en: And that that serotonin and its related pathways can help enhance some of the immune system function that could combat the infection.

captions.zh: "现在有一些初步的数据，我要强调是初步，因为相关研究还不多，看看补充像5-HTP这样的血清素前体，或者吃能自然增加血清素的食物，是否有效。"
captions.en: There is starting to be some data, and I emphasize starting because it's not a very robust literature yet, looking at whether or not supplementing precursors to serotonin like 5-HTP, which can be taken in supplement form, or consuming foods that increase serotonin naturally.

captions.zh: "所以就是含有高色氨酸的食物。"
captions.en: So these would be any foods that contain high levels of tryptophan.

captions.zh: 你可以查查这些食物是什么。
captions.en: You can look up what those are.

captions.zh: 比如白肉火鸡，还有一些复杂碳水也富含色氨酸。
captions.en: So white meat turkey, for instance, certain complex carbohydrates can often be rich with tryptophan.

captions.zh: 吃这些食物可以增加大脑和血液中的血清素，从而改善睡眠质量，促进更深层次的修复。
captions.en: That consuming those foods can enhance the amount of serotonin that's available in the brain and blood, and thereby lead to the particular quality of sleep that allows for more deep healing.

captions.zh: "我说的深层修复，其实就是为了更强的免疫反应。"
captions.en: Or for, when I say deep healing, I mean for a more robust immune response.

captions.zh: "不过，这些数据还在不断更新。"
captions.en: Now, again, those are still emerging data.

captions.zh: 不过，很明显的是，在睡觉时，尤其是在任何病毒或细菌感染的早期阶段，所谓的脑淋巴系统会比平时活跃得多。
captions.en: What is very clear, however, is that during sleep, and in particular during sleep that's associated with the early stage of any kind of viral or bacterial infection, the so-called glymphatic system is much more active than it would be normally.

captions.zh: "什么是脑淋巴系统？"
captions.en: What's the glymphatic system?

captions.zh: "脑淋巴系统其实是最近才发现的。"
captions.en: The glymphatic system is actually a relatively recent discovery.

captions.zh: "我刚才提到过淋巴和淋巴系统。"
captions.en: I mentioned lymph and the lymphatic system earlier.

captions.zh: "脑淋巴系统是大脑里的一个系统，可以清除白天积累的垃圾，尤其是神经炎症和身体炎症时产生的垃圾。"
captions.en: The glymphatic system with a G is a system in the brain by which debris that accumulates throughout the day, but in particular, debris that accumulates under conditions of neuroinflammation and inflammation of the body is cleared out or is washed out of the brain.

captions.zh: "脑淋巴系统的活跃对从各种感染中恢复非常重要。"
captions.en: And the activity of this glymphatic system is extremely important for the recovery from infection of any kind.

captions.zh: "现在已经很清楚，脑淋巴系统对脑外伤恢复很重要，甚至可能对心理创伤的恢复也有帮助。"
captions.en: And it's now becoming clear is important for recovery from traumatic head injury and maybe even from psychological trauma.

captions.zh: "所以，脑淋巴系统有点像管道系统，贯穿脑室，还主要在大脑和颅骨之间的那层膜，以及其他一些组织中运行。"
captions.en: So the glymphatic system can be thought of more or less as a plumbing system that runs through the ventricles, but also mainly through the lining that sits between the brain and the skull and some of the other tissues and things of that sort.

captions.zh: "脉络丛也参与其中。"
captions.en: The choroid is involved as well.

captions.zh: "脑成像显示，脑淋巴系统在深度睡眠时特别活跃。"
captions.en: Brain imaging reveals the glymphatic system is very active during deep sleep.

captions.zh: "还有就是淋巴系统会有种清洗作用。"
captions.en: And there's this kind of washout of the lymphatic system.

captions.zh: 我知道现在有些研究正在进行，通过补充色氨酸、5-HTP，甚至直接补充血清素来增强血清素系统，这些都是实验室研究，看看能否增加脑淋巴系统的循环量。
captions.en: And I am aware of some studies that are ongoing now where augmenting the serotonin system through either supplementation of tryptophan or 5-HTP or even serotonin itself, these are laboratory studies, is being looked at for its capacity to increase the amount of circulation in the glymphatic system.

captions.zh: "这个想法是，可能会加快受伤和疾病的恢复速度，也可能增强免疫系统的活跃程度。"
captions.en: And the idea is that it might, and I want to underscore might, potentially lead to more rapid recovery from injury and illness and potentially ramp up, if you will, the activity of the immune system.

captions.zh: 所以这基本上就是在增强免疫系统的活跃度。
captions.en: So it essentially is a ramping up of the activity of the immune system.

captions.zh: 不管你睡前是不是打算补充5-HTP，我待会儿会聊聊这个，正常情况下也有办法提高脑淋巴系统的活跃度。
captions.en: Now, regardless of whether or not you decide to, for instance, supplement with 5-HTP before sleep or not, I'll talk about what that might look like in a moment, there is a way that you can increase the activity of your glymphatic system under normal circumstances.

captions.zh: 因为脑淋巴系统的运作机制，结果发现如果你睡觉时把脚抬高个12度左右，不一定非得是12度，可以在脚下垫个卷枕头或两个枕头，把头放在腿下，这样睡觉时好像能增加脑淋巴的清洗效果。
captions.en: Because of the mechanics of the glymphatic system, it turns out that if you elevate your heels by about 12 degrees, it doesn't have to be exactly 12, as you sleep by putting maybe a rolled pillow or two pillows underneath your feet, by having the head below your legs, it seems that there's more glymphatic washout or clearance during sleep.

captions.zh: "而且这不需要吃任何东西来调整血清素系统。"
captions.en: And this is without taking any compound to adjust the serotonin system.

captions.zh: 所以我会说，如果你感觉不舒服，去洗个热水澡，然后上床睡觉，但记得抬高双脚，试试增加脑淋巴系统的活跃度。
captions.en: So I would say, if you're not feeling well, yes, take the hot shower, yes, get into bed and go to sleep, but elevate your feet to try and increase the activity of the glymphatic system.

captions.zh: 有些人甚至觉得，如果非得醒着，那可能也想让脚高于头。
captions.en: Some might even consider that if you have to be awake, that you might want to be awake with your feet elevated above your head.

captions.zh: "这可能不太适合在工作场合，但白天小憩一下或者类似情况倒是可以试试。"
captions.en: Now that might not be practical for the workplace, but it might be practical for a short nap during the day or something of that sort.

captions.zh: 脑淋巴系统不仅在睡觉时活跃，在我们特别放松的时候醒着也会活跃。
captions.en: The glymphatic system is not just active during sleep, it's also active during certain phases of waking in particular, when we are in a deep state of relaxation.

captions.zh: 很多人可能知道，我挺推崇自我催眠的，因为有很多高质量的科学研究支持。
captions.en: So as many of you probably know, I'm a big proponent of self-hypnosis because of the quality scientific literature on this.

captions.zh: 如果你对自我催眠感兴趣，可以去Reveri，R-E-V-E-R-I.com看看。
captions.en: If you're interested in self-hypnosis, you can go to Reveri, R-E-V-E-R-I.com.

captions.zh: Reveri 是个免费的苹果和安卓应用，由我在斯坦福医学院的同事 David Spiegel 和其他人开发，基于优质研究和同行评审的数据，显示深度放松状态可以帮助缓解疼痛、改善入睡时间和其他一些方面。
captions.en: Reveri is a cost-free app for Apple and Android that was developed by my colleague, David Spiegel and others at the Stanford University School of Medicine based on quality studies and peer reviewed data, showing that deep states of relaxation can be used to improve pain management, improve transition time to sleep and a number of other things.

captions.zh: 你可以用Reveri选择你想要的效果。
captions.en: You can select the various sort of outcomes that you're seeking using Reveri.

captions.zh: 对于那些觉得冥想有难度的人来说，这挺好的，因为只需要听着引导，就能进入深度放松状态。
captions.en: It's a great thing that, especially for people that are challenged with meditation could use because you just listen to the script, involves deep relaxation.

captions.zh: 我建议你用那个放松或睡眠的引导，但把脚抬高，能促进大脑清理废物的系统活动。
captions.en: I would suggest using that script or the script for sleep, but with feet elevated to increase activity of the glymphatic system.

captions.zh: "如果你想自己试试这个血清素假说，记得先问医生。"
captions.en: Now, if you do decide that you want to test out this serotonin hypothesis on your own, obviously check with a doctor.

captions.zh: “我不是医生，我是教授。”
captions.en: I'm not a doctor, I'm a professor.

captions.zh: 所以我是分享知识，不是给建议。
captions.en: So I'm professing things, not suggesting things.

captions.zh: “但是5-HTP这个补充剂，我之前在播客里提过，我其实不建议大多数人用来改善睡眠，因为它可能会打乱正常的睡眠结构，导致晚上早期进入深度睡眠，然后突然醒来，很难再入睡。”
captions.en: But 5-HTP is a supplement that I've talked about before on this podcast that I actually do not recommend for most people for sake of sleep because it can disrupt the normal architecture of sleep and create a deep sleep early in the night and then a spontaneous waking with some trouble to get back to sleep.

captions.zh: "这是因为血清素系统和褪黑素系统的相互作用。"
captions.en: And that's because of the way that the serotonin system and the melatonin system interact.

captions.zh: 不过，如果你觉得自己可能感染了或者刚生病，这种情况下，5-HTP可能有用，能帮助进入一些不太常见的睡眠状态。
captions.en: However, under conditions where one is feeling like they might have an infection or an early stage of illness, in that case, 5-HTP might be a useful supplement in order to access these states of sleep that are not typical.

captions.zh: "那不是你健康时能达到的正常深度睡眠。"
captions.en: They're not the typical deep sleep that you would achieve on when you're feeling healthy.

captions.zh: 这些睡眠状态主要是为了修复免疫系统相关的炎症。
captions.en: These are states of sleep that are specifically there in order to try and repair some of the immune system related inflammation that's occurring.

captions.zh: 如果你想试试5-HTP，而且觉得适合自己，也跟医生聊过，那就可以在睡前30到60分钟服用300到500毫克。
captions.en: If you'd like to explore the 5-HTP approach and you feel it's right and safe for you and you've talked to your doctor, it's 300 to 500 milligrams taken about 30 to 60 minutes before going to sleep for the night.

captions.zh: "这就是一般的方法。"
captions.en: That's the typical protocol.

captions.zh: "顺便说一下，提高血清素也是治疗重度抑郁症的常用方法。"
captions.en: Not incidentally, increasing serotonin is also one typical approach for the treatment of major depression.

captions.zh: 这就是像Prozac和Zoloft这样的SSRI，也就是选择性血清素再摄取抑制剂的基础。
captions.en: This is the basis for things like SSRIs, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, like Prozac and Zoloft and so forth.

captions.zh: "当然，5-HT这种方法比处方药温和多了，但能促进血清素的合成和释放。"
captions.en: The 5-HT approach is a much milder approach than prescription drug, of course, but will allow more serotonin to be synthesized and or released.

captions.zh: 对了，如果你对学习更多关于脑脊液系统感兴趣，这个系统挺有意思的。你可能想深入了解一下它的行为模式和已知信息。
captions.en: Now, for those of you that are interested in learning more about the glymphatic system, it's a fascinating system and you might want to do a deep dive there in terms of the behavioral protocols and what's known about it.

captions.zh: 有篇不错的文章叫《脑淋巴系统入门指南》。
captions.en: There's a wonderful article called The Glymphatic System, A Beginner's Guide.

captions.zh: 这是一篇科学文章。
captions.en: This is a scientific article.

captions.zh: 第一作者姓Jessen，J-E-S-S-E-N。
captions.en: The first author is Jessen, is the last name, J-E-S-S-E-N.

captions.zh: 你只要在网上搜Jessen，《脑淋巴系统入门指南》，就能轻松找到完整的文章。
captions.en: If you put in Jessen, The Glymphatic System, A Beginner's Guide, you can access the full-length manuscript easily online.

captions.zh: 一搜就能马上找到。
captions.en: It'll show up immediately in your search.

captions.zh: 而且很有意思的是，脑淋巴系统现在也和铁沉积系统有联系了。
captions.en: And in a really interesting way, the glymphatic system has now also been tied to the iron deposition system.

captions.zh: 之前我们聊到铁的问题。
captions.en: Earlier, we were talking about iron and how.

captions.zh: 铁摄入够当然重要，但如果铁含量太高，就有很多问题。
captions.en: Of course, getting enough dietary iron is important, but if levels of iron are too high, it isn't good for a number of reasons.

captions.zh: 有篇去年出的有趣文章，说大脑淋巴系统功能失调可能跟正常衰老时铁沉积有关。
captions.en: There's a very interesting article that just came out last year called dysfunction of the glymphatic system might be related to iron deposition in the normal aging brain.

captions.zh: 所以我们开始发现，铁含量过高、大脑淋巴系统不够活跃，这些可能导致生病行为、炎症，甚至可能跟衰老相关的神经元损伤。
captions.en: So we're starting to see these links between iron levels being too high, the glymphatic system not being active enough, and so forth leading to sickness behavior, inflammation, and maybe even damage to neurons associated with aging.

captions.zh: 我们可以反过来说，增加大脑淋巴系统的活跃度，比如深睡时抬高双脚，甚至在清醒时抬脚高过头部，或者每天小憩时做个冥想练习，这些都可能提高大脑淋巴系统的活跃度。
captions.en: We can flip that on its head and say that increasing the activity of the glymphatic system, feet elevated during deep sleep, maybe even feet elevated above the head while awake, during a nap, or doing a reverie script once a day or something of that sort could increase the activity of the glymphatic system.

captions.zh: 降低铁摄入到可能低于感染期的典型摄入量，可能会增强大脑淋巴系统的活跃度，反之亦然。
captions.en: Lowering iron to a point that's probably below the typical intake during periods of infection, perhaps, perhaps, I should say, can enhance the glymphatic system and vice versa.

captions.zh: 然后，有种跟生病行为相关的特殊睡眠，似乎有更高的血清素水平，可能通过摄入5-HTP来增强。
captions.en: And then you've got this specialized sleep that's related to sickness behavior that seems to have heightened levels of serotonin that might be augmented by increasing, excuse me, that might be augmented by ingesting 5-HTP.

captions.zh: "当然，这不是每天都要做的。"
captions.en: Again, not on a regular basis.

captions.zh: 我不建议大家随便吃提升血清素的东西，除非是医生给你开的治抑郁症的药。平时不要经常补充色氨酸或5-HTP，只有在你感觉开始生病，或者感染的时候才考虑。

captions.zh: 主题还挺多的，随机试验，双盲测试，结果都看到鼻塞明显减轻，嗅觉改善，睡眠质量提高，每天工作的细胞因子和炎症因子也减少了，鼻子痒的症状也减轻了。可以想象，吃两克螺旋藻后会有这些效果，有时候需要吃一阵子才能见效。
captions.en: So decent number of subjects, randomized trial, double-blind, both cases saw significant decreases in nasal obstruction, improved ability to smell, improved sleep, daily working cytokine, inflammatory cytokines were reduced as well, reduction nasal itching, all the stuff that you'd like to experience, I can imagine, after taking two grams, two grams, not milligrams, but two grams of Spirulina, sometimes had to be taken for a short while before the effect kicked in.

captions.zh: 所以说，这效果挺不错的，不过这还没解释原理。不过在研究螺旋藻对减轻鼻炎的作用机制时，发现螺旋藻能抑制所谓组胺肥大细胞的形成或活性，这点挺有意思的。
captions.en: So that's pretty impressive, I would say, but it doesn't really speak to mechanism, but in exploring the underlying mechanisms for Spirulina's effects on reducing rhinitis, it's interesting to find that Spirulina actually can inhibit the formation and or activity of so-called histaminergic mast cells, M-A-S-T, mast cells.

captions.zh: "我们还没怎么聊过肥大细胞，但它们在免疫反应中挺有意思的。"
captions.en: We haven't talked a lot about mast cells, but they are a very interesting cell type in the immune response.

captions.zh: "基本上，它们就是一些组胺的小包。当我们皮肤受伤或者受到刺激，比如被蚊子咬了，或者碰到毒橡树、毒常春藤之类的东西，导致皮肤痒或者体内炎症，不一定只是皮肤上的反应。"
captions.en: Essentially what they are, little packets of histamine, and when we have some sort of injury or irritant, rather, to the skin, so a mosquito bite, for instance, or poison oak or poison ivy, something that causes an itch or something that causes inflammation internally, it doesn't just have to be on the skin.

captions.zh: 这些肥大细胞就像小气泡，里面有组胺，会跑到刺激部位释放组胺，导致局部细胞肿胀和发炎。
captions.en: These mast cells are these little bubbles that contain histamine that go to that site and release their histaminergic contents and cause swelling and inflammation of whatever cells are affected locally.

captions.zh: "你可能会想，为什么身体里会有导致肿胀和发炎的机制呢？"
captions.en: That's cause, you might think, well, why would I want to have a mechanism in my body that would cause swelling and inflammation?

captions.zh: "哦，然后这些细胞会释放细胞因子信号，招募我们之前提到的那些先天免疫系统的细胞，比如巨噬细胞，还有其他会吞噬外来入侵者或者帮助隔离和清除毒素的细胞。"
captions.en: Ah, well, then those cells, in turn, send out cytokine signals that recruit the very cell types that we were talking about way back at the beginning of the episode, the cells that are characteristic of the innate immune system that come in, the macrophages and the other types of cells that will come in and gobble up the foreign invaders or will help sequester and move away, say, the poison from a bite or from whatever irritant.

captions.zh: "而且不只是皮肤表面才会这样。"
captions.en: Again, it doesn't just have to be at the skin surface.

captions.zh: 我这是在举个皮肤上的例子。
captions.en: I'm describing an example at the skin.

captions.zh: 比如说，你要是起过荨麻疹，那肯定和肥大细胞有关。
captions.en: For instance, if you've ever had hives of any kind, that almost certainly involved mast cells.

captions.zh: 所以，当你吃抗组胺药来对付季节性过敏时，其实就是在减少肥大细胞里的组胺。而螺旋藻也被证明在治疗季节性过敏方面很有效，效果跟一些主要的处方药和非处方药差不多。
captions.en: So, and when you take an antihistamine, antihistamine, in order to deal with seasonal allergies, for instance, you're dealing, you're, excuse me, you're taking a compound that's reducing histamines in mast cells, and spirulina has also been used quite effectively as a way to treat seasonal allergies and some of the symptomology equally on par with some of the major prescription and over-the-counter drugs for that.

captions.zh: 不过要提醒一下，螺旋藻对有遗传突变导致苯丙酮尿症的人可能有副作用。
captions.en: One cautionary note, spirulina does, can carry some side effects for people that are, have a genetic mutation leading to something called PKU.

captions.zh: 这些人自己知道的。
captions.en: These people know who they are.

captions.zh: 他们对苯丙氨酸特别敏感。
captions.en: They're very sensitive to phenylalanine.

captions.zh: 这些人也不能喝任何营养饮料或健怡汽水，他们自己明白原因。
captions.en: These same people cannot drink any sort of nutritious or diet soda for reasons that they understand.

captions.zh: "可能会挺危险的。"
captions.en: It could be quite dangerous.

captions.zh: 虽然是个罕见的遗传病，但螺旋藻对这些人还是有问题。
captions.en: It's a rare genetic disorder, but nonetheless, spirulina can be an issue for those people.

captions.zh: 大多数人基本没什么副作用。
captions.en: For most people, the side effect profile is pretty minimal.

captions.zh: "说清楚，我跟螺旋藻公司没任何关系。"
captions.en: And just to be clear, I don't have any relationship to a spirulina company or anything.

captions.zh: "我就觉得有意思，这些东西听起来有点新潮，因为它们来自藻类、植物，但看它们的作用机制，其实挺合理的。"
captions.en: I just find it interesting that there are these compounds that sound rather, forgive the phrase, but rather new agey because they come from a algae, from a plant, but when you look at the underlying mechanism, it makes perfect sense.

captions.zh: 所以，我们常常想指出的是，如果有这种所谓的替代疗法，之所以叫替代疗法是因为大多数人没听说过，最好是能有个明确的原理和框架来解释它们的作用，而不是只听说"哦，我听说螺旋藻对过敏很好"这种说法。
captions.en: So that's often what we like to point out here is that if there are these so-called alternative therapies, alternative because most people haven't heard of them, it's always nice if they map to a specific logical mechanism and framework by which that compound would work as opposed to just some anecdote of, oh, I hear spirulina is great for allergies.

captions.zh: "哦，现在我们知道原因了，它抑制肥大细胞，特别是组胺肥大细胞。"
captions.en: Well, now we know why, it inhibits mast cells and histaminergic mast cells in particular.

captions.zh: "之前我提到过一项很新鲜、很激动人心的研究，已经在《自然》上发表了完整文章。"
captions.en: Earlier, I mentioned a new and very exciting study published as a full article in Nature.

captions.zh: "完整文章就是说明这是个重大发现。"
captions.en: Full article means that it is a major finding.

captions.zh: "在《自然》杂志上，他们有些信件，都是重要的发现。"
captions.en: At the journal Nature, they have letters, which are important findings.

captions.zh: "要在《自然》上发表信件也挺严格的，但完整文章通常每周刊里就一两篇。"
captions.en: They're still very high stringency for getting a letter in Nature published, but the full articles, generally, there's only one or two per issue in the weekly edition of Nature.

captions.zh: 上周，哈佛医学院Chufu Ma的实验室发表了一篇很有意思的文章。
captions.en: And just last week, there was a very exciting article published from Chufu Ma's lab at Harvard Medical School.

captions.zh: "Chufu，我认识他好多年了。"
captions.en: Chufu, I've known for a number of years.

captions.zh: "他的团队在研究瘙痒和疼痛机制方面做得非常出色，发现了一些相关的受体和通路。"
captions.en: His group has done phenomenal work on the mechanisms of itch and pain and discovering some of the receptors and pathways for itch and pain.

captions.zh: 最近，他们还在研究针灸的机制基础。
captions.en: And more recently, they've been exploring the mechanistic basis of acupuncture.

captions.zh: 文章标题是“电针刺激迷走肾上腺轴的神经解剖基础”。
captions.en: And the title of the article is a neuroanatomical basis for electroacupuncture to drive the vagal adrenal axis.

captions.zh: "虽然这名字有点拗口，但大多数人应该都懂我说的迷走肾上腺轴是什么。"
captions.en: And while that's a mouthful, now, most all of you are probably familiar with what I mean when I say vagal adrenal axis.

captions.zh: "迷走是指迷走神经，肾上腺是指肾上腺。"
captions.en: Vagal, meaning of the vagus and adrenal of the adrenal glands.

captions.zh: 所以，当楚夫的实验室研究所谓电针刺激身体时，我们可能不意外，但还是很兴奋。
captions.en: And so perhaps we should not be surprised, although excited nonetheless, that when Chufu's lab looked at stimulation of the body with so-called electroacupuncture.

captions.zh: “所以这些针就是通过针头传递微弱电流进到身体里。”
captions.en: So these are needles where it's a small bit of electrical current, low level of electrical current is passed into the needle and therefore into the body.

captions.zh: "他们找到了身体上可以通过释放炎症因子来增加炎症的部位。"
captions.en: They located sites on the body that can increase inflammation by way of releasing inflammatory cytokines.

captions.zh: "这些部位包括腹部，他们还发现像下肢这样的地方可以刺激迷走肾上腺反射，从而减少炎症。"
captions.en: These areas included the abdomen and they found areas on the body such as the lower limbs or the hind limbs in this case that can stimulate the vagal adrenal reflex and can lead to reduced inflammation.

captions.zh: "有意思的是，他们发现是筋膜里的神经末梢被激活了。"
captions.en: And what was really interesting is that they figured out that it was activation of nerve endings that resided in the fascia.

captions.zh: 我之前提到过筋膜是什么，简单说就是包裹肌肉的一层厚组织。
captions.en: I mentioned earlier what fascia is, but just to remind you, the fascia is a really thick sheath of tissue that surrounds muscle.

captions.zh: 如果你听说过罗尔夫按摩，这是一种很强烈的按摩方式。
captions.en: If ever you've heard of rolfing, rolfing is a form of very intense massage.

captions.zh: 我没试过，但听说过。
captions.en: I've never had this done, but I've heard about this.

captions.zh: "它其实包括把肌肉和筋膜稍微分开。"
captions.en: It involves among other things, actually separating the muscle away from the fascia somewhat.

captions.zh: 所以这就是一种很深层的按摩。
captions.en: So it's a very, very deep tissue massage.

captions.zh: "我有个朋友做过，他说这可能是他经历过最难受的身体体验之一。"
captions.en: Actually a good friend of mine who had this done told me that it was probably the most challenging experience that physical experience that he'd ever been through going through this rolfing procedure.

captions.zh: "可能有些人试过罗尔夫按摩，可以分享一下感受，到底是舒服还是不舒服，有没有效果。"
captions.en: Maybe some of you have been rolfed as they say and can report to the experience whether or not it was pleasant or unpleasant or you felt benefits or not.

captions.zh: 反正，这研究不是专门讲罗尔夫按摩，而是关于筋膜的。
captions.en: In any case, this study isn't about rolfing per se, but it is about the fascia.

captions.zh: 所以他们发现有一类特定的神经元。
captions.en: And so what they discovered is there's a specific population of neurons.

captions.zh: 那些神经元有个名字，科学上经常这样。
captions.en: Those neurons have a name as they often do in science.

captions.zh: 名字不重要，不过你要查的话，是PROC-R2神经元。
captions.en: Name isn't important, but if you want to look it up, it's the PROC-R2 neurons, P-R-O-K-R2 neurons.

captions.zh: "它们深入连接到四肢的筋膜组织。"
captions.en: And they send a connection deep into the limb fascial tissue.

captions.zh: "然后，它们再发出另一个连接。"
captions.en: Okay, and then they send another connection.

captions.zh: 我们说的连接其实就是轴突。
captions.en: The connections we're referring to are axons.

captions.zh: 神经元有轴突。
captions.en: Neurons have axons.

captions.zh: "所以有一根线往一个方向深入到腿部的筋膜组织，靠近小腿和大腿。"
captions.en: So a wire in one direction that goes into the deep fascial tissue of the lower limb and near the calf and thigh.

captions.zh: 然后它们再发出一根线，往上连接到脊髓，进入靠近颈部的大脑后面的延髓区域。
captions.en: And then they send another wire up into the spinal cord and to a region of the hind brain in the back of your brain kind of near your neck called the medulla in the medulla oblongata.

captions.zh: 那个神经元也有个名字叫DMZ，不过这不重要。
captions.en: That neuron also has a name called the DMZ, doesn't matter.

captions.zh: "然后那个神经元连接到肾上腺，释放我们熟悉的儿茶酚胺，像去甲肾上腺素、肾上腺素和多巴胺。"
captions.en: And that neuron connects to the adrenal gland to release our good old friends, the catecholamines, noradrenaline, adrenaline, and dopamine, or norepinephrine, epinephrine, and dopamine.

captions.zh: "这些物质一释放，就能减轻炎症，即使是面对能引发发烧的脂多糖注射也有效。"
captions.en: And their release causes a reduction in inflammation, even in response to an injection of something called lipopolysaccharide, which can actually induce fever.

captions.zh: "那这说明了什么呢？"
captions.en: So what is all this saying?

captions.zh: "这就是说，深筋膜组织的激活会引发一连串神经反应，最终释放去甲肾上腺素、肾上腺素和多巴胺。"
captions.en: This is saying that activation of the deep fascial tissue causes a chain of neural reactions that leads eventually to the release of norepinephrine, noradrenaline, adrenaline, and dopamine.

captions.zh: "这又能降低炎症，很像我们之前提到的呼吸研究，还有那种循环换气和屏息的方式，也能减少炎症。"
captions.en: And once again, lowers inflammation, very much like the breathing study that we talked about earlier and the pattern of cyclic hyperventilation with retention leading to reductions in inflammation.

captions.zh: "这真让我太高兴了。"
captions.en: I can't tell you how happy this makes me.

captions.zh: "我跟这个研究没关系，但让我高兴的是，那些存在了几百年甚至几千年的方法，比如针灸和呼吸法，开始和一些硬核的机械科学结合起来了。"
captions.en: I had nothing to do with this work, but the reason it makes me happy is because I have a particular fondness for when practices that have existed for many centuries or even thousands of years, such as acupuncture, such as respiration work, start to converge with some of the hardcore mechanistic science.

captions.zh: "让我兴奋的原因不是因为我们想用科学取代这些古老方法，完全不是这样。"
captions.en: And the reason this excites me is not because we want to take science and erase the previous tools and methods of these ancient practices, not at all.

captions.zh: "我们也不是想用现代科学给这些东西起新名字。"
captions.en: And it certainly isn't the case that we just want to name things or rename things with modern science.

guest.name: Andrew Huberman 博士
guest.title: 斯坦福大学医学院神经生物学与眼科学教授
guest.bio: Huberman 博士的研究专注于大脑发育、神经可塑性以及神经再生。作为科学传播者，他致力于将前沿神经科学研究转化为可实践的健康工具。

summary.zh: 你的大脑能控制免疫系统吗？在本期节目中，Andrew Huberman 博士带你深入探索神经系统与免疫系统之间令人惊叹的双向连接。从哈佛医学院最新发表在《自然》杂志上的针灸研究，到脑淋巴系统如何在睡眠中清理大脑废物，再到呼吸练习如何激活抗炎反应——这不是玄学，而是有充分科学证据支持的生理机制。Huberman 博士将解析免疫系统的三层防御体系，揭示发烧、炎症等看似令人不适的症状背后的生存智慧，并分享多种经过验证的方法来增强免疫功能。
summary.en: Can your brain control your immune system? In this episode, Dr. Andrew Huberman explores the fascinating bidirectional connections between your nervous system and immune system, from Harvard's latest Nature publication on acupuncture to how the glymphatic system clears brain waste during sleep.

keyPoints.title: 针灸的科学机制
highlights: 哈佛医学院研究发现，刺激特定筋膜组织可以通过神经通路触发肾上腺释放抗炎分子
针灸通过激活副交感神经系统，能够快速降低全身炎症水平
这项研究为传统中医疗法提供了现代神经科学的解释

keyPoints.title: 睡眠与免疫清洁
highlights: 脑淋巴系统（glymphatic system）在深度睡眠时活跃度提升10-60倍
睡眠期间大脑会清除代谢废物和免疫系统产生的炎症因子
抬高双脚睡觉可能通过改善淋巴回流来增强这一清洁过程

keyPoints.title: 呼吸调节炎症
highlights: 特定的呼吸模式（如生理性叹息）能够实时激活副交感神经系统
通过控制呼吸节奏，可以在几分钟内降低体内炎症水平
这种方法完全免费且随时可用，是增强免疫的实用工具

keyPoints.title: 心态即药物
highlights: 心理状态和动机水平能直接影响免疫细胞的迁移速度
积极的心态可以加快伤口愈合效率高达25%
心理-神经-免疫连接比我们想象的更加直接和强大

highlights.title: 针灸激活抗炎通路
highlights.zh: 哈佛医学院Chufu Ma的实验室在《Nature》上发表了一篇论文，研究针灸如何减少身体的炎症。
highlights.en: Harvard Medical School's Chufu Ma lab published a Nature paper on how acupuncture reduces inflammation.

highlights.title: 发烧的智慧
highlights.zh: 前视区的神经元会让体温升高，引发发烧，这是身体对抗感染的重要机制。
highlights.en: Neurons in the preoptic area raise body temperature to induce fever, a crucial defense mechanism.

highlights.title: 脑部清洁系统
highlights.zh: 脑淋巴系统是大脑里的一个系统，可以清除白天积累的垃圾，尤其是神经炎症和身体炎症时产生的垃圾。
highlights.en: The glymphatic system clears accumulated waste from the brain, especially during inflammation.
